bestBHT.bht: As the second seal is opened, the second living being proclaims, Come and see. The omission of and see in some manuscripts emphasizes the seal being opened. Revealing a white horse and its rider, this symbolizes a departure from the conquering horse and signifies important events in God's providential governance. While the ministers under this seal may lack the strength of their predecessors, they are diligent in their preaching and patient in their suffering. The voice of the ox, lower than the lion, suggests a decrease in Gospel ministry, yet the ministers invite John to witness this vision, turning towards the west, the primary focus of this seal.

Henry Alford: And when he opened the second seal, I heard the second living-being saying, Come (see above on ver. 1).
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: three oldest manuscripts, A, B, C, and Vulgate.
Albert Barnes: And when he had opened the second seal - So as to disclose another portion of the volume.

All that seems to be designed is, that as the living creatures are intended to be emblems of the providential government of God, it was proper to represent that government as concerned in the opening of each of these four seals, indicating important events among the nations.
Marvin Vincent: Had opened [ηνοιξεν] . Rev., rendering the aorist mow literally, opened.
Archibald T. Robertson: The second seal (την σφραγιδα την δευτεραν). "The seal the second." The white horse with his rider vanished from the scene bent on his conquering career.
John Gill: no mention is made of the noise of thunder, as before, the voice of the ox being lower than that of the lion; and this perhaps may point out a decrease in the Gospel ministry.

the ministers of the Gospel are intended who lived under this seal, who, though they might not be strong and courageous like the lion, or their predecessors, yet were like the ox, laborious in preaching, and patient in suffering.
these are represented in this vision as inviting John to behold and observe the following hieroglyphic.
John Wesley: And when he had opened the second seal, I heard the second living creature — Who looked toward the west.
Saying, Come — At each seal it was necessary to turn toward that quarter of the world which it more immediately concerned.

bhtAttempts.bht: As the second seal is opened, the second living being speaks, Come and see. The omission of and see in some manuscripts highlights the focus on the opening of the seal. The second seal reveals a white horse and its rider, signifying a shift from the conquering horse to a different portrayal. This suggests that the opening of each seal discloses important events in God's providential government. While the ministers under this seal may not possess the strength and courage of their predecessors, they are diligent in their preaching and patient in their suffering. The voice of the ox, lower than the lion, may symbolize a decrease in the Gospel ministry. Yet, it is the ministers themselves who invite John to observe this hieroglyphic, turning towards the west, the quarter of the world it primarily concerns.

The voice of the ox, lower than the lion, may symbolize a decrease in the Gospel ministry. Yet, the ministers invite John to observe this vision, turning towards the west, the quarter of the world it primarily concerns.

As the second seal is opened, the second living being declares, Come and see. The omission of and see in some manuscripts highlights the seal being opened. A white horse and its rider symbolize a shift from the conquering horse, revealing significant events in God's providential governance. While the ministers under this seal may lack the strength of their predecessors, their diligent preaching and patient suffering are admirable. The voice of the ox, lower than the lion, hints at a decrease in Gospel ministry. Nonetheless, these ministers invite John to observe this vision, turning towards the west, the primary concern of this seal.
